DataElement.preferredName: Uterine Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Regional Lymph Node N Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the regional lymph node involvement for the uterine carcinoma based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Corpus Uteri Neoplasm Pathologic N Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The Corpus uteri, or body of uterus, is the part of the uterus above the isthmus, comprising about two thirds of the non-pregnant organ._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The Corpus uteri, or body of uterus, is the part of the uterus above the isthmus, comprising about two thirds of the non-pregnant organ.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: The Corpus uteri, or body of uterus, is the part of the uterus above the isthmus, comprising about two thirds of the non-pregnant organ.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Corpus Uteri Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 N Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of uterine corpus carcinoma, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Carcinosarcomas should be staged as carcinoma. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. N refers to the extent of lymph node involvement._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN2 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN2 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Uterine corpus carcinoma with regional lymph node metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes, with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN2 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Uterine corpus carcinoma with regional lymph node metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes, with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN0 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN0 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Uterine corpus carcinoma with no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN0 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Uterine corpus carcinoma with no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN1 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN1 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Uterine corpus carcinoma with regional lymph node metastasis to pelvic lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pN1 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Uterine corpus carcinoma with regional lymph node metastasis to pelvic lymph nodes. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pNX TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pNX TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Uterine corpus carcinoma in which regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Uterine Corpus Carcinoma pNX TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Uterine corpus carcinoma in which regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)
